feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 4 at 3:11PM HST until March 6 at 6:00AM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...WINTER STORM WARNING FOR THE BIG ISLAND SUMMITS...
* WHAT...Periods of freezing rain, mainly at night, leading to significant icing. Additional ice accumulations of around one half of an inch.
* WHERE...Big Island Summits.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM HST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be impossible.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM HST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 4 at 8:10PM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
Patchy fog has developed this evening over portions of Volusia, northern Brevard, Seminole, eastern Orange, and far northeastern Lake Counties. Through late evening, light northeast winds will attempt to push this patchy fog deeper across East Central Florida. Locations such as Deland, Deltona, and Sanford may begin to see visibility restrictions. This includes portions of Interstates 95 and 4.
Visibilities may briefly drop to a half mile or less. Drivers should prepare to encounter rapid visibility reductions. When driving in fog, slow down, use only low beam headlights, and leave extra following distance between your vehicle and the one in front of you.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Inland Volusia; Northern Lake County; Orange; Seminole; Inland Northern Brevard; Inland Southern Brevard; Mainland Southern Brevard

cap:parameter.value: Patchy Dense Fog Developing Over Portions Of East Central Florida, Northeast Of Orlando

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 4 at 8:08PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
entry.summary:
At 808 PM EST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 7 miles east of Rockford, or 10 miles southwest of Greenville, moving northeast at 40 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Greenville... Stanton... Belding... Rockford... Edmore... Grattan... Crystal... Sidney... Sheridan... McBride... Westville... Gowen... Wells Airport... Cedar Lake... Entrican... Vestaburg... Turk Lake... Wyman... Greenville Municipal...Smyrna...

cap:parameter.value: A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of northeastern Kent, northwestern Ionia and Montcalm Counties through 915 PM EST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 4 at 4:58PM PST by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
At 457 PM PST, a snow squall was located 12 miles east of Hayden Lake, or 13 miles east of Dalton Gardens, moving northeast at 55 mph.
Locations impacted include... Spokane Valley, Coeur d'Alene, Post Falls, Hayden, Rathdrum, Dalton Gardens, Liberty Lake, Hayden Lake, Green Acres, Otis Orchards-East Farms, Otis Orchards, Fourth Of July Pass, Fernan Lake Village, Huetter, State Line, Cataldo, Magee Ranger Station, Chilco, and Valleyford.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 90 in Washington between mile markers 294 and 299. Interstate 90 in Idaho between mile markers 0 and 29. U.S. Highway 95 in Idaho between mile markers 417 and 444. U.S. Highway 195 in Washington between mile markers 82 and 89.
Conditions can deteriorate rapidly in winter weather situations. Be prepared for snow or ice covered roads. Slow down and allow extra time when traveling.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coeur d'Alene Area; Central Panhandle Mountains; Spokane Area; Northeast Mountains

cap:parameter.value: A SNOW SQUALL WILL AFFECT NORTHWESTERN SHOSHONE...CENTRAL KOOTENAI AND EAST CENTRAL SPOKANE COUNTIES

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 4 at 4:26PM PST until March 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT... For the Winter Storm Warning above 1500 feet, heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 6 inches with up to 12 inches over higher remote terrain. For the Winter Weather Advisory above 500 feet, wet snow. Snow accumulations of up to 2 inches.
* WHERE...For the winter storm warning, elevations above 1500 feet in central Douglas County and eastern Douglas County foothills. This includes the passes on I-5, the Tiller-Trail highway, and portions of highway 138 east of Steamboat. For the winter weather advisory, elevations above 500 feet in the Umpqua Basin.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 10 AM PST Tuesday. For the Winter Storm Warning, until 4 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels could vary from 500 feet up to 3000 feet in this zone depending on where the front sets up this evening through tonight. Heavy precipitation could pull down snow levels lower than anticipated.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM PST TUESDAY ABOVE 500 FEET... ...WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST TUESDAY ABOVE 1500 FEET

entry.summary:

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels will be about 2500 feet to the north and 4500 feet to the south.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 4 at 6:08PM CST until March 4 at 7:45PM CST by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
At 608 PM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 1.5 to 2.5 inches in 1 hour. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... New Orleans, Chalmette, Timberlane, Harvey, Belle Chasse, East New Orleans, Marrero, Metairie, Jefferson, Gretna, Westwego, Arabi, Terrytown, Meraux, Violet, Woodmere, Bridge City and Lakefront Airport.
This includes the following Interstates... Interstate 510 between mile markers 1 and 3. Interstate 10 in Louisiana between mile markers 230 and 248. Interstate 610 between mile markers 1 and 4.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jefferson, LA; Orleans, LA; Plaquemines, LA; St. Bernard, LA

cap:parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 745 PM CST THIS EVENING FOR NORTH CENTRAL JEFFERSON, SOUTHWESTERN ORLEANS, NORTHWESTERN PLAQUEMINES AND WEST CENTRAL ST. BERNARD PARISHES
NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 7:45 PM CST. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 7:45 PM CST. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 4 at 2:51PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Low pressure tracking into the gulf Tuesday will swing a front towards the panhandle. As the front moves over SE AK, precip is likely for much of the panhandle beginning Tuesday night and lasting through Wednesday. The last few days have been clear and cold so the area is set up for snow at the start. At this time, because the expected movement of the front is from west to east, the amounts of snow does not look enough for a significant winter storm.
Confidence is increasing on 24 hour amounts estimated between 4 - 8 across the panhandle; however, amounts are trending towards the lower end of the spread. With southerly winds picking up in lieu of the heaviest snowfall, temperature profiles look to limit substantial (above 6 inches) snowfall for areas that are not the northern panhandle. This is supported in the NBM probabilities of 6 inches or greater trending down with every model run. Latest guidance is suggesting most locations have roughly a 30% chance of achieving 6 or more inches in a 24 hour period.
For snow type, areas along the coast and southern panhandle look to have dry, fluffy snow to start, but as heavier rates move in, snow will quickly become heavy and wet. For areas in the northern panhandle, expect snow to remain light, dry, and possibly accumulate quickly. Elsewhere, snow looks to begin as light and dry and slowly become increasingly wet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: ACCUMULATING SNOW LIKELY BEGINNING TUESDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 4 at 5:19PM CST until March 4 at 8:30PM CST by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
FFWLIX
The National Weather Service in New Orleans has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Northwestern Jefferson Parish in southeastern Louisiana... Western Orleans Parish in southeastern Louisiana... East Central St. Charles Parish in southeastern Louisiana...
* Until 830 PM CST.
* At 519 PM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... New Orleans, Avondale, Metairie, Marrero, Jefferson, Harahan, Westwego, Elmwood, Bridge City, River Ridge, Waggaman, Estelle, Woodmere and New Orleans Armstrong Airport.
This includes the follwing Interstate... Interstate 10 in Louisiana between mile markers 222 and 230.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jefferson, LA; Orleans, LA; St. Charles, LA

* WHERE...A portion of southeast Louisiana, including the following parishes, Jefferson, Orleans, Plaquemines, St. Bernard and St. Charles.
* WHEN...Until 730 PM CST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.

This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... New Orleans, Timberlane, Harvey, Chalmette, Belle Chasse, Marrero, Metairie, East New Orleans, Avondale, Jefferson, Gretna, Harahan, Westwego, Terrytown, Arabi, Woodmere, Meraux, Estelle, Bridge City and Violet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 4:00PM EST until March 6 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.
Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Richland, Calhoun and Lexington Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Carolina Eastman.
* WHEN...Until Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 115.0 feet, Flooding occurs in low lying areas of the Carolina Eastman Facility and at the Congaree National Park. At 119.0 feet, Extensive flooding occurs in the Congaree National Park. Some area farmland is flooded. Minor flooding occurs at the Carolina Eastman Facility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:56 PM EST Monday the stage was 117.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 114.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage tomorrow morning and continue falling to 112.5 feet Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 115.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Calhoun, SC; Lexington, SC; Richland, SC

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL WEDNESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 4:00PM EST until March 7 at 1:00PM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.
Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Richland, Calhoun and Lexington Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Congaree National Park-Gadsden.
* WHEN...Until early Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Flooding begins in the Congaree National Park. This will begin to produce flooding of portions of the lower boardwalk. At 17.0 feet, The access road to the Sandy Run subdivision becomes flooded. The lower boardwalk in the Congaree National Park becomes flooded by Cedar Creek.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 PM EST Monday the stage was 16.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 16.8 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Wednesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Connecticut...Rhode Island...
Pawcatuck River At Westerly affecting Washington and New London Counties.

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

It will then rise to 6.7 feet late Wednesday morning. It will fall to 6.6 feet early Wednesday afternoon. It will then rise above flood stage early Thursday morning to 7.5 feet late Thursday morning. It will fall to 7.3 feet late Thursday morning then rise again. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued March 4 at 4:01PM AST until March 6 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents due to breaking waves up to 8 feet.
* WHERE...North and east-facing beaches of Puerto Rico and Culebra. Eastern beaches of St. Croix.
* WHEN...Through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; North Central; Northwest; Culebra; St Croix

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 4 at 10:11AM AKST until March 5 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow expected. Total snow accumulations of up to one inch. Winds gusting as high as 50 mph.
* WHERE...Northwest Arctic Coast.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 45 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: Blizzard Warning issued March 4 at 10:11AM AKST until March 5 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions expected. Total snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph.
* WHERE...Western Arctic Coast.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 40 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.

cap:parameter.value: BLIZZARD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 11:58AM CST by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Louisiana...
Bodcau Bayou At Bayou Bodcau Lake affecting Webster and Bossier Parishes.
For the Bodcau Bayou...including Bayou Bodcau Lake...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Bodcau Bayou at Bayou Bodcau Lake.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 AM CST Monday the stage was 175.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 171.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:00 AM CST Monday was 175.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 175.0 feet this afternoon. - Flood stage is 172.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 175.0 feet on 05/29/1968. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 12:49PM EST by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santee River near Jamestown.
* WHEN...From late tonight until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, several dirt logging roads are impassable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1230 PM EST Monday, the stage was 9.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early Tuesday morning and continue rising to 12.8 feet Friday evening. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Berkeley, SC; Georgetown, SC; Williamsburg, SC

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued March 4 at 12:18PM EST until March 4 at 10:00PM EST by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...Walton County Beaches.
* WHEN...Until 9 PM CST this evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Morning beach cams show some elevated surf where single red flags are currently flying at Walton County beaches.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM CST THIS EVENING

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 5 at 3:06AM ChST until March 5 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 7 to 9 feet.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Kosrae.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM ChST this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The long-period north swell will continue to slowly subside. Surf will remain elevated along north and east facing reefs through this afternoon, falling below hazardous levels later today. Surf is expected to build again Wednesday along east facing reefs as a building trade swell moves into the the region.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM CHST THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 10:32AM CST by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas... Louisiana...
Sabine River Near Deweyville
For the Sabine River...including Burkeville, Bon Wier, Deweyville, Orange...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Tuesday morning at 1045 AM CST.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Sabine River near Deweyville.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 24.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding will occur.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 AM CST Monday the stage was 24.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:45 AM CST Monday was 24.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 24.4 feet. - Flood stage is 24.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
